translated: Verses of the Elder Nuns .
The Book of Twenties

analyzed: subhā kammāra dhī tutherī gāthā  daharā aham suddha vasanā
translated: The Elder Nun Subhā, Daughter of the Blacksmith
When I was young, wearing pure white clothes,🔽I listened to the Dhamma in the past.
Through my diligence,

analyzed: sacca abhisamayaḥ ahu  tatas ham sabba kāmesu
translated: I attained the truth.🔽Then I lost all interest
in all sensual pleasures.
Seeing the danger in existence,

analyzed: nekkhammam iva pīhaye  hitvā an aham ñāti gaṇa  dāsa kammakarāni ca
translated: I longed for renunciation.🔽Abandoning my relatives,🔽my slaves and workers,
My prosperous villages and fields,
so delightful and delightful to behold,

analyzed: pahā ayam aham pabbajitā  sāpateyyam anappaka
translated: I went forth,🔽leaving behind my great wealth.
Thus, having gone forth out of faith,
in the well-proclaimed true Dhamma,
It would not be fitting for me
to seek out the worthless.
For one who has abandoned gold and silver
should not return to them.
Gold and silver
do not lead to awakening or peace.
This is not suitable for an ascetic,
this is not the wealth of the noble ones.
It is a cause of greed, intoxication,
delusion, and increase of defilements.
It is full of danger, with much anxiety,
there is no lasting stability in it.

analyzed: ettha rattā pamattā ca  saṅkiliṭṭha manāḥ narā
translated: Those who are attached and heedless,🔽those people with defiled minds,
are mutually hostile,
and they make their own misfortune.
Slaughter, bondage, and affliction,
grief and lamentation arise.
For those who are devoted to sensual pleasures,
many kinds of misfortune are seen.
Me, your relatives, as if I were an enemy,
why do you delight in sensual pleasures?
Know that I have gone forth,

analyzed: kāmesu bhaya dassini  na hirañña suvaṇṇena
translated: seeing danger in sensual pleasures.🔽The taints are not exhausted
by gold and silver.
Sensual pleasures are enemies, killers,
foes, and fetters.
Me, your relatives, as if I were an enemy,
why do you delight in sensual pleasures?

original: Jānātha maṁ pabbajitaṁ,🔽muṇḍaṁ saṅghāṭipārutaṁ.🔽Uttiṭṭhapiṇḍo uñcho ca,
analyzed: jānātha mama pabbajita  muṇḍam saṅghāṭi pāruta  uttiṭṭha piṇḍaḥ uñchaḥ ca
translated: Know that I have gone forth,🔽shaven-headed, wearing an outer robe.🔽Alms-food, gleaning,
and rag-robes as robes—
this is suitable for me,

analyzed: an agārūpa nissayaḥ  vantā mahesīhi kāmā
translated: dependent on going forth.🔽Sensual pleasures, whether divine or human,
have been abandoned by the great seers.
They are liberated in a safe place,
they have attained unshakable happiness.
I am not entangled by sensual pleasures,
in which there is no refuge,
Sensual pleasures are enemies, killers,
like a mass of flames, painful.

analyzed: paripanthaḥ esa bhayaḥ  sa vighātaḥ sa kaṇṭakaḥ
translated: This is a dangerous path,🔽with violence and thorns,
this is a snare, very uneven,
a great opening for delusion.
This is a calamity, fearful in form,
sensual pleasures are like a snake’s hood;
The foolish delight in them,
blind ordinary people.
In the mud of sensual pleasures,
many beings in the world are ignorant;
They don’t know the end
of birth and death.
The path that leads to a bad destination,
humans because of sensual pleasures
often practice,
bringing on their own illness.
Thus sensual pleasures give rise to enemies,🔽they torment and defile,
worldly sensual pleasures are binding,
sensual pleasures are a fetter to death.🔽Sensual pleasures are maddening, intoxicating,
they make the mind intoxicated;
for the defilement of beings,
they are quickly seized by Māra.
Sensual pleasures have endless dangers,
many sufferings, great poison,
little satisfaction, they create conflict,
they purify the bright side.
Having done such things,
because of sensual pleasures,
I will not return,
always delighting in Nibbāna.
Having waged war against sensual pleasures,
desiring the state of complete peace,
I will live heedful,
in the destruction of all fetters.
The sorrowless, dust-free, safe,
straight path with eight factors,
I follow that path
by which the Great Seer crossed over.”
“Look at this one who is firm in Dhamma,
Subhā, the daughter of the smith;
Having attained the unshakable,
she meditates at the foot of a tree.
Eight days after going forth,
with faith in the beautiful Dhamma,
trained by Uppalavaṇṇā,
she has become one who has conquered Death.
Now she is a teacher, debt-free,
a nun with developed faculties;
she is detached from all bonds,
her work done, without taints.”
Then Sakka, with a group of gods,
approached her with psychic power;
the Lord of Beings paid homage to her,🔽Subhā, the daughter of the smith.
… the Elder Nun Subhā, the daughter of the smith …
The twentieth chapter is finished.
